issues.description: The problem statement (and UML) specifies acceptSupplyDelivery should take four parameters (supplier name, ingredient name, price, quantity) but the solution implementation defines acceptSupplyDelivery with only three parameters (ingredient name, price, quantity). This is a method parameter mismatch between the specification and the provided solution. Students reading the UML/description would implement a different signature than the solution, causing confusion and making comparisons with the reference implementation or tests unclear.
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the signature between specification and implementation. Either (A) update the solution to implement acceptSupplyDelivery(String supplierName, String ingredientName, int price, int quantity) (the supplierName may be unused or stored if desired), or (B) change the problem statement/UML to specify a three-parameter signature (ingredientName, price, quantity). Prefer option A to preserve the information requested in the problem text: implement the 4-parameter method and ignore or store the supplierName inside the method implementation.

issues.description: The problem statement UML and textual description specify acceptSupplyDelivery with four parameters (supplier name, ingredient name, price, quantity) while both the provided template (Main.java usage) and the solution implement acceptSupplyDelivery with three parameters (ingredient name, price, quantity). This mismatch between the problem spec and the code artifacts can confuse students about the expected method signature (which parameters to implement and in which order).
issues.suggested_fix: Resolve the signature mismatch. Either (A) update the problem statement (UML and description) to specify a three-parameter acceptSupplyDelivery(String ingredientName, int price, int quantity) to match the template Main usage and the solution implementation, or (B) update the solution and any example calls to implement the four-parameter signature acceptSupplyDelivery(String supplierName, String ingredientName, int price, int quantity). Prefer option A if the supplier name is not used in the exercise logic; otherwise, prefer B and document how the supplier name is used.
